job_title: C N A in Denton, TX
pros: Flexible schedule, paid training for techs
cons: Typical hospital drama. Nurses feel superior to techs, doctors feel superior to nurses. Gossip

pros:
Denton Regional has a great teaching culture and strives to build their employees to be the best in their field. When I was hired by Regional I had little experience, after just a few months of training I was able to hit the ground running and have never stopped since. 

Regional is a great place to start, learn, and build a network of peers. They also value their employees and have a good education-tuition reimbursement package. This was a huge plus amidst the low wages.
cons:
Overworked, understaffed and underpaid.  

Although I began my career with Regional, all my years there I felt I could never catch up. Just like in any company, you have low seasons and downtime, but when it came to busy times we rarely had enough staff and consistently had someone on vacation or as a last minute call-in. This caused a lot more stress for the employee, especially the ones that had to be called in to cover last minute. (Consistently)

 From observation and experience, this was across all departments in the hospital. (Nursing, Imaging, Lab, and even the environmental services.)

This type of environment caused at times large divisions within staff and made for staffing to doubt their current employment at Regional. 

Many of us that have left are thankful for the experience and opportunity, but once out in the market, we were able to see how little compensation we were getting.

For example, only after 2 years of being entry level, I was offered a $6 dollar hourly increase with another company. At the time, I took the offer but also remained PRN due to loyalty to my coworkers and manager.

HCA does not compensate their employees well for the amount of hard work they do every day.  Most coworkers would say that salary wouldn't be as bad if we were always fully staffed.

pros: If you're working part-time, the pay is very good for a student or recent graduate because you don't get any benefits of insurance or PTO. You get free meals and snacks here and there.
cons: Everyone is out to get you. Employees are always side-eyeing you to see if you fail. If you do, they report you. You get written up for calling in, being sick, inclement weather, and flexing off. They favor certain employees while others complain. They don't care about employees.

review_title: This was the best experience of my life.
job_title: Imaging Services Director in Denton, TX
pros: I learned many new processes, as well as improved on the skills I already have.  The staff and administration at DRMC is one of the best.  They are teamwork oriented and always ready to help each other.
cons: There really aren't any cons that I can list.  The facility is very busy and does stretch employees to the max, but the budget does not allow for additional staff.

review_title: Some of the nicest people. Hard working conditions. High turnover in Pacu.
job_title: Registered Nurse BSN in Providence, RI
pros: Good teaching hospital, the nicest people, easy parking. Friendly. Good care by the nurses.  Decent pay, friendly doctors. Good place for New nurses.
cons: Very poor management. Favoritism. Unfair treatment by those not qualified to be in mangament.. unstable job, for profit hospital which means it's about the money. No supplies,  they have a lot of lay offs. Especially on Friday afternoons. As nurses we doubled as housekeeping. Yes we cleaned bathrooms. Very high turnover in my department, unsafe at times. Stressful. Managers walk out at 430 and leave the unit full of patients and unsafe. You never knew when you were leaving. Ever. Caused hard feeling amongst staff, causing the high turnover .

pros: critical care nursing is one of the most challenging experiences in nursing. The critical care nurse is proficient in the care of medical, surgical patients at every critical level. Icu is also responsible for the care of the most critically ill oncology patients including but not limited to bone marrow transplants, as RWMC has the only bone marrow transplant unit in RI.
cons: Staffing is always an issue and sometimes nurses have difficulty managing patients in the way we feel is necessary for their optimum care. Ancillary staff is always inadequate.

pros: Work with a good team of people, most who seem to really care about their positions and work extremely hard despite being under staffed. Also most of my co-workers are vert knowledgable.
cons: Communication is terrible. Most of the time the three components that make up the IT Dept don't know what the other is working on.

pros: Fair pay and employee appreciation dinner after 5 years of service.
cons: Fair pay only to lose in paying high benefits. Great place to work if you have no integrity. No room for growth, Job title does not jive with job description. New CEO, doesn’t hurt to say hello to the employees. Ratings are negative across the border, was the worst experience in the past 3 years. No respect for loyal employees.

pros: Good starting pay, decent medical, good ETO
cons: Recently bought by Prospect CharterCare and are now for profit.  Insurance co-pays have significantly increased and yearly pay rate went down to a maximum of 2%
